section.title: Checking In
section.para: On arrival, sign in at the front door. If the rep or alternate does not have a pass card, an officer will escort him to the security station.

Once appropriately signed in, enter the EOC, pick up the copy of this position manual in the bookshelf near the door, and go to the Auxcomm desk (Second row, left most two chairs when facing the command diaz). Note that the coordinator is expected to have the official copy of this document at the desk.
Log on to MI-CIMS, make an entry in the Activity Log noting you are in the SEOC. Make the record shared with agency and SEOC.

section.title: Assessing the situation
section.para: The rep must first get a feel for the current situation. On MI CIMS, quickly review the Incident Action Plan, if one is available. Also, review the most recent entries in the SEOC Significant Events and the Statewide Significant Events boards.
This should be done quickly so that the jurisdiction can be contacted. Often there will be considerable detail to be studied, but first the jurisdiction must be contacted.

section.title: Contact local jurisdiction
section.para: When the SEOC has been activated, one of the first tasks is to contact the DEC for the affected jurisdiction. In many cases, of course, the DEC may have contacted the SEC in the first place. Even in those cases, contact the DEC so (s)he is aware that the SEOC is activated. ()
The local ECs affected must also be notified. When speaking with the DEC, decide whether the DEC will notify the ECs or whether they will each get a call from Harris Drive. ()
Be sure to determine, whether through the DEC or directly with the ECs, the communications circuits to be used between the SEOC and the local EOC.
After contacting the DEC, then contact the Net Manager of the net responsible for the affected District. ()
Advise leaders of CAP, MARS and SATERN of the activation. They will most likely not be required to respond, but they should be aware of the incident.

section.title: Situation Report
section.para: After the initial contacts have been made, review the Incident Action Plan once again, paying attention to the incident objectives. If there is no IAP yet, there may be an ICS-202 Incident Objectives under the Reference Info menu. Take care, depending on the incident, there may be a 202 per agency. Be sure to select a relevant 202.

Under SEOC Situation Report- Agency List, AuxComm, Edit Record enter the three Auxcomm objectives for the incident. Consider the objectives for the next operational period (e.g. where will you get resources). List any concerns you have.
Briefly assess the status of each service, and summarize the status in the various ... SITUATION UPDATES fields. Also in this field list the names and calls of all operators at the SEOC.

Returning to the top of the form, briefly summarize the Auxcomm situation in the EXECUTIVE SUMMARY field. This will become part of the of the SEOC Situation Report - Published so it wants to be at a very high level. If the Auxcomm section of the SEOC Situation Report - Published should be blank, leave this blank.

From time to time come back to this board to update the situation. Occasionally, the Planning Section will ask for this form to be complete. When that happens, review the board to be sure it says what you want to say.

section.title: Liaison with the station
section.para:
One of the rep's primary function is to provide a communications path between the station status and the various agencies.
Apprise the various agencies of the current station status if needed
Communicate the current status of the field situation, as understood by the SEOC, to the station.
Alert the station of any communications needs of the agencies.
If possible, spend some time with the operators prior to the exercise to understand the situation there.
The coordinator will typically communicate with the station via telephone. See for numbers.

warning.title: Things change
warning.para: The SEOC facility is new, the phones may not be permanent, and the intercom system might not yet be functional. You may need to physically check the phone number in the station, and/or communicate with the station via HT.

section.para: The coordinator and the station should also agree on a backup communications plan. Typically, the coordinator and a station op should have HTs. A simplex channel should be agreed upon since the station's primary VHF radio will likely be monitoring a repeater involved in, or relaying for, the incident.
Stay in regular touch with the station; be aware of their situation and whether they are in contact with the site. Keep them up to date as to site changes as announced in the SEOC.
If the MARS station is active, be sure to stay abreast of the MARS SitRep and include them in hourly updates. Similarly if REACT, SATERN or other services are involved.

section.title: Requests
section.para: From time to time, the Logistics chief or the Ops chief may ask for status information from the field or other communications into the affected area. Be aware of the available circuits and field resources so that these requests may be routed most effectively. Keep in mind that event though their resources are limited, MARS may well have personnel in an appropriate position to respond to the request.

Often, we are the only agency with a communications focus. In effect, the AuxComm EMC becomes the Communications Unit leader. Do not be surprised if the request is far outside a simple radiogram, and consider both your unique skills, and the considerable resources available at the SEOC to respond to the request.

section.title: Agency Announcements
section.para: Periodically, the Director or Ops Section Chief will ask for agency updates. Give a brief status of the station for each update. Keep in mind that the agency reps are non-technical, but most realize that we are their backup plan. Give a meaningful status without getting technical. Where possible get information on the program status at the local jurisdiction and, if significant, pass this along to the other agencies as well.
Pay attention to the other agency reports. Should they need us our job will be eased if we at least have some familiarity with their situation.

Consider updating the station with any interesting items from the other agencies. Depending on the drill and players, there may be EOCs on the converse bridge unaware of the situation at the site and in need of update.

section.title: Debrief
section.para: At the end of the exercise, there will be a debrief from all agencies. Prior to this check with the station operators to be sure you are aware of any contact with the site or nearby jurisdictions. Often, the station operators may be invited into the SEOC for the final debrief.
Make a positive, brief presentation when asked. As usual, avoid technical details and focus on capability.
